profiles.display: English (UK) – clipped clarity – en-GB – Receives vowels tuned for eSpeak en-gb
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object default
Statements fall in pitch at the end
stress: Primary stress ˈ, secondary ˌ
Non-rhotic endings drop /r/ unless followed by vowel

profiles.display: English (US) – tactile vowels – en-US – Foundational Latin alphabet mapping derived from eSpeak en-us
grammar: Common digraphs ch, sh, th prefer affricate forms
sentenceStructure: Default Subject–Verb–Object order
Interrogatives raise pitch near the end
stress: Primary stress marked with ˈ before the syllable
Secondary stress marked with ˌ

profiles.display: English (US) – Heritage Eloquence – en-US – Pronunciation cues transcribed from JAWS, Window-Eyes, and Loquence studio dictionaries
grammar: Heritage voices favour rhotic endings; keep "r" audible even after schwa
Assimilate nasal + stop clusters (nk, mp) for smoother phrase prediction playback
Diphthongs collapse in unstressed syllables, mirroring the 6.1 dictionary
sentenceStructure: Declaratives keep a mid-low plateau before dropping on the final syllable
Questions rise sharply across the last stressed vowel, matching classic Eloquence focus
stress: Primary stress uses Loquence-style lengthening on the vowel nucleus
Secondary stress keeps the consonant attack sharp as in heritage JAWS

profiles.display: French – nasal warmth – fr-FR – Core French characters tuned against eSpeak fr defaults
grammar: liaison links final consonants to following vowels
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object with frequent pronoun drop in imperatives
Intonation rises slightly for yes/no questions
stress: Lexical stress falls on the final full syllable
Function words keep flat intonation

profiles.display: German – precise articulation – de-DE – Key German letters referencing eSpeak de voice
sentenceStructure: Verb-second declaratives
Verb-final subclauses
stress: Primary stress typically on first syllable
Compound words keep secondary stresses

profiles.display: Hindi – retroflex energy – hi-IN – Core Devanagari characters tuned against eSpeak hi phonemes
grammar: Aspiration distinguishes minimal pairs such as क /k/ vs ख /kʰ/
sentenceStructure: Subject–Object–Verb order with postpositions
Yes/no questions rise on the final syllable
stress: Primary stress usually falls on the first heavy syllable
Schwa deletion occurs at word endings when following consonant clusters

profiles.display: Italian – open vowels – it-IT – Italian vowel core tied to eSpeak it voice
grammar: Open/closed e and o contrast meaning
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object with flexible clitics
Questions marked by rising phrase-final pitch
stress: Stress generally on penultimate syllable
Accents indicate irregular stress

profiles.display: Japanese – mora rhythmic – ja-JP – Kana coverage with pitch-accent guidance for NVDA phoneme hints
grammar: Long vowels and geminated consonants count as separate mora
The moraic nasal ん assimilates to following consonant place
sentenceStructure: Topic–Comment structure with Subject–Object–Verb order
Particles anchor grammatical roles and affect intonation
stress: Pitch accent typically falls on the second mora of a word
Unaccented words sustain high pitch until the final mora

profiles.display: Portuguese (Brazil) – vibrant vowels – pt-BR – Brazilian Portuguese nasal set mapped from eSpeak pt-br
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object with topicalisation flexibility
Yes/no questions rely on rising contour
stress: Default stress on penultimate syllable
Accent marks signal deviations

profiles.display: Spanish (Castilian) – crisp sibilants – es-ES – Castilian defaults matching eSpeak es
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object standard
Clitics attach before conjugated verbs
stress: Penultimate syllable carries stress unless accent marks override
Interrogatives use rising intonation

profiles.display: Spanish (LatAm) – sonorous core – es-419 – Latin American Spanish vowels and consonants following eSpeak es-la
sentenceStructure: Subject–Verb–Object with flexible pronoun drop
Questions rise sharply at the end
stress: Acute accent carries primary stress
Default stress on penultimate syllable
